description: There is an abundance of evidence suggesting that the standard economic paradigm - rational agents in an efficient market - does not adequately describe behavior in financial markets. In this course, we will survey the evidence and use psychology to guide alternative theories of financial markets. Along the way, we will address the standard argument that smart, profit-seeing agents can correct any distortions caused by irrational investors. Further, we will examine more closely the preferences and trading decisions of individual investors. We will argue that their systematic biases can aggregate into observed market inefficiencies. The second half of the course extends the analysis to corporate decision making. We then explore the evidence for both views in the context of capital structure, investment, dividend, and merger decisions.
name: BEHAVIORAL FINANCE

values.comments:
In FNCE 739 students will survey the evidence and use psychology to guide alternative theories of financial markets. Along the way, the class will address the standard argument that smart, profit-seeing agents can correct any distortions caused by irrational investors. Further, the class will examine more closely the preferences and trading decisions of individual investors. The class will argue that their systematic biases can aggregate into observed market inefficiencies. The second half of the course extends the analysis to corporate decision making. The class will then explore the evidence for both views in the context of capital structure, investment, dividend, and merger decisions.

Students commented that FNCE 739 “provides several pretty important and practical set of caveats to the traditional Corp Fin everyone takes.”  Specifically, students commented that the course “provides a pretty good alternative for thinking about the capital markets.” A significant number of students found the hedge fund project “interesting,” but felt that the part of their grade based on this project was based “effectively upon chance.” Nevertheless, a minority of students felt that the class material was “boring.”

Most students commented that Professor Yuan that he was “very hard to follow.” Other students commented that he “could not communicate the subject matter” and that he had difficulty answering student questions. Some students suggested that this difficulty may stem from a possible language barrier.

Many students felt that grades in this course should not have been so strongly influenced by the hedge fund project. The prerequisites for this course include FNCE 611 or 612 and FNCE 613. FNCE 720 and FNCE 726 are recommended.
